results.title: Cohuna celebrates the coronation of QE II
results.brief_description: When Cohuna Higher Elementary School wanted to raise money for a film projector, local resident Tom Olsson decided to help by filming life in the township and surrounding countryside, and then showing the footage in the local Town Hall. His footage has been lovingly compiled by the Cohuna Historical Society and the resulting films give us a special glimpse into rural life in 1950’s Victoria. The school recieved their projector, and Olsson’s films were shown annually as a Christmas treat for many years afterward. This segment documents the QEII Coronation parade in 1952.

results.title: reLOCATED - The Venny kids
results.brief_description: reLOCATED was a community arts project documenting the lives of residents from the Kensington Public Housing Estate who were relocated when the estate was redeveloped. Bailey and Costi’s photography, writing and audio recordings have been combined into short video works especially for the MAP project that allow us to observe instances of beauty in city life while also celebrating the multiple forms of community and history to be found in Melbourne’s inner-West. The Venny was the local playground for kids from the estate, and ‘The Venny Kids’ pays tribute to a place that has seen many happy times.

results.title: Momma don't allow
results.brief_description: This early key work by Karel Reisz and Tony Richardson follows a group of young English men and women going out and exploring the jazz clubs of London. Made as part of the Free Cinema documentary movement, Momma Don’t Allow is observational rather than didactic, capturing the joy and pleasure of music, going out and being part of a gang.

results.title: Reassemblage: from the firelight to the screen
results.brief_description: This poetic yet intellectually rigorous documentary begins as an essay on Sengalese women but transforms to become an essay on the very subject of documentation, historical truth and Eurocentric “objectivity”. Trinh T. Minh-ha’s work has been pivotal in challenging cinematic assumptions about the representation of being “other”. Combining passionate theory with elegiac images “Reassemblage” is a critical history of the documentary and ethnography and one of the key works of Post-Colonial cinema.

results.title: acmipark
results.material_description: interactive software, computers, monitors, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
acmipark is multiplayer virtual world. Created by selectparks (artists Julian Oliver, Chad Chatterton, and Andrea Blundell), it was designed to extend the physical spaces of the Australian Centre for the Moving Image (ACMI) at Melbourne’s Federation Square into the realms of virtual space. It was produced using a game engine as its base, and worked up from the real architectural designs produced for Federation Square by Lab Architecture Studio.

Designed as a soundpark, it is a musical instrument which can be played collectively, and, like Federation Square itself, it was envisaged as a kind of public space waiting for a community to define its meaning.

It was conceived as an experiment in the design of a virtual public space. It is an embodiment of the idea that we are moving our public space into the realm of the virtual. By using a model of a real world public space combined with the collaborative possibilities of the soundpark and the kinaesthetic pleasures of moving through a beautiful virtual place, selectparks hoped to build upon traditional concepts of ‘public’ places.

[Source: Helen Stuckey, 2006 https://firstmonday.org/ojs/index.php/fm/article/view/1561/1476 last accessed 20/10/2020]

results.title: First Touch
results.brief_description: Using archival films of the Apollo lunar missions in the late 1960s and early 70s, this 2 screen video installation contemplates humankind’s first touch of the moon. Often considered a giant leap in human development, the video concentrates on the delicate and hesitant movements of the astronauts and their spaceships as they overcome the limits of outer space. With both humour and melancholy, stunning images of the moon, the earth, and the astronauts and their spacecraft, are interwoven into a wondrous contemplation of this extraordinary achievement.

results.title: End Game
results.creator_credit: Emma Crimmings, Michael Fairlie and Rhys Graham
results.brief_description: Using the fragments, clock leaders and strips of films found at the beginning and end of hundreds of old 16mm films, this Public Imaging work explores the visual beauty of the film’s surface. Concealed among ACMI’s vast film collection, these pieces of film are a testament to the aging wonder of celluloid. The play of light and colour that can be found in the interweaving of these accidents and offcuts makes for a hypnotic experience.

results.title: L'Eclipse du Soleil en Pleine Lune

video_links.name: L'Eclipse du Soleil en Pleine Lune

results.brief_description: An aging astronomer invites students to his castle observatory to observe a solar eclipse. Amid the childish pranks of the novice astronomers and the wondrous vision of the eclipse, George Melies, cinema’s great magician, weaves numerous amusing set pieces. Much to the astronomer’s excitement, the sun and the moon flirt with each other as they come together in an astronomical courtship and the sky explodes in a dance of female stars. On earth, the astronomer falls prey to his cheeky students who rob him of his stately dignity, while the heavens smile down on him from above.
